definition:
A *combinatorial principle* is any statement $\Phi$ of set theory proved
to be independent of Zermelo-Fraenkel (ZF) set theory, usually one with
interesting consequences.

If $\Phi$ is a combinatorial principle, then whenever we have
implications of the form $$P\implies \Phi\implies Q,$$ we automatically
know that $P$ is unprovable in ZF and $Q$ is relatively consistent with
ZF.

Some examples of combinatorial principles are the , the continuum
hypothesis, $\Diamond$, $\clubsuit$, and Martin’s axiom.

[9]{} Just, W., .
